tossups.question: This scientist names a fluid which can be modeled as a dashpot filled with a Newtonian Fluid that is connected in series to a perfectly elastic spring. He names a method of fixing oscillatory isotherms of the van der Waals equation by drawing a horizontal line that sweeps out equal areas. His study of Watt's centrifugal governor was one of the earliest forays into control theory, and he names a construct which was shown to acquire too much information entropy in its brain to be feasible, a follow-up to an argument made by Leo Szilard.  This physicist added the displacement current term to one law which related current to magnetic field and published it and 3 others in "On Physical lines of Force." Those 4 equations include the aforementioned Ampere's law, Faraday's law, and 2 versions of Gauss's law. FTP, name this physicist who names the set of equations which governs electromagnetism.

His experience as a schoolteacher led him to join the government as a minister of education. This man's wife was rumored to have partaken in orgies with high society members such as the movie star Alain Delon, a fact exposed in the Markovic Affair.  This man, who died from Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia, offered to resign from one position to persuade the President to pardon Edmond Jouhaud for his role in the Generals' Putsch. This man was nominated to one post despite not being a member of the National Assembly, and that body was dissolved after it attempted to force him out. He defeated Alan Poher to take his highest post, and this man's work on the Grenelle Agreements is credited with leading to a peaceful resolution to May 1968 civil unrest.  For 10 points, name this prime minister under  de Gaulle who succeeded him as President and names a Renzio Piano-designed Paris landmark.

In this novel, the protagonist's waiter at a restaurant was once raped by a man who died while playing football on Thanksgiving Day. The narrator compares that man's penis size to the penis size of Harry LeSabre and the two main characters. While the protagonist of this novel is sitting alone in a parking lot, Mary Young is dying in a hospital with only Cyprian Ukwende by her side. The protagonist of this novel beats his son and wife, because he believes a book he reads which tells him that he is the only one with free will. The protagonist's object of obsession is a writer who appears in other works by the same author. For 10 points, name this novel that takes place in Midland City and centers on Dwayne Hoover's obsession over Kilgore Trout's writings, a work of Kurt Vonnegut.

This man once repeatedly ordered his followers to rebuild a wall he had knocked down, then told them off for blindly following orders. He once chastised a man for riding around on a flying carpet by hiding himself in plain sight and comparing the man to the insects, and in another story he deflected the black magic of the women of Kamrup. This man was often accompanied by his friends Bala and Mardana. As a child, a cobra once shielded this man from the sun. The Janamsakhis are biographical records of this figure, who was succeeded by his friend Angad. This man outlined the three pillars of sharing, earnest earning, and chanting Gods name, or Vand Chakko, Kirat Karo and Naam Japna, which were recorded in the Adi Granth. For 10 points, name this religious leader who proclaimed "There is no Hindu, there is no Muslim", the first guru of Sikhism.

One of this man's chamber works quotes the folk song "There in the Willows Stands a House" in the adagio movement and was explicitly written to include an instrument without valves. This man's first piano trio starts in B major but end in B minor, and his Opus 120 clarinet sonatas were both written for Richard MÃ¼hlfield, for whom he also wrote a work modeled after a Mozart composition for Anton Stadler. Though not Cesar Franck, this composer of a Piano Quintet in F Minor and a Clarinet Quintet in B minor also composed two contrasting overtures of which he said "one laughs, the other cries." The first of those was written as a thank you for an honorary doctorate degree from the University of Breslau, and this man's first symphony is sometimes called "Beethoven's Tenth."  For 10 points, identify this German composer of the Academic Festival Overture?

This quantity increases as one goes up the Irving-Williams series, and Bjerrum developed a method of calculating these values by altering the pH of a solution. For a metal-ligand complex, this value is equivalent to the stability constant of the complex. The change in Gibbs free energy is proportional to the negative ln of this value, which can only be calculated using activities of the species involved. This value was defined by Guldberg and Waage in their Law of Mass Action, and this value is equal to the rate of the forward reaction divided by the rate of the reverse reaction. Comparing this value to the reaction quotient is a common method of applying Le Chatlier's principle.  For 10 points, name this constant calculated as products over reactants, usually symbolized K.
tossups.answer: Equilibrium Constant [or K or stability constant before mention]

tossups.question: This author wrote a story in which a sinner is denied entrance to heaven by Peter and David, but finally allowed in by John. Another story by this author tells of the title character's inability to marry Ustinja because of his father. The protagonist of another story by this author accepts a deal from the Bashkirs and tries to mark out a large area with a spade in one day but ends up dying from exhaustion and is buried in a six-foot-long grave. This man wrote about a child who is sent to be a servant after he breaks the title object to earn his nickname. This author of the short stories "Alyosha the Pot" and "How Much Land Does a Man Need" as well as the "Sevastopol Sketches" also wrote a novella in which the title judge falls off a ladder, fatally injuring himself. For 10 points, name this Russian author of "The Death of Ivan Ilyich" and War and Peace.

One side-quest in this game requires the player to retrieve a cage containing a rare insect and bring it back to a man who screams "THANK YOU" whenever you purchase something from him. One boss in this game requires using the whip to unscrew him and is a six-armed, Buddha-like automaton named Koloktos. After failing to protect his love interest, Groose builds a bomb catapult on rails to guard a sealed temple, and the second part of this game requires the player to purify a legendary weapon with three sacred flames. The events of this game are set in motion with the appearance of a tornado sent by the villainous Ghirahim and the disappearance of a blonde maiden, and this game's hub world is explored by flying around on a Loftwing. Famed for its one-to-one controls with Motion Plus, for 10 points, identify this Wii game in which Link descends from the clouds with the title blade, the latest entry in the Legend of Zelda series.
tossups.answer: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword
acceptable: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword

tossups.question: One fragmentary inscription dedicated to this man had a fourth line reference to his positions and was found in Hippo Regius. He declined a British military tribuneship obtained for him by Pliny the Younger, who this man may have followed to Bithynia. This author of the Playground which included De Gramaticis et Rhetoribus was dismissed along with the Praetorian Septicus Clarus for rude behavior towards Empress Sabina. He did not write about the current dynasty in his best-known work, whose opening section on the origins of the Julian clan are lost.  He managed libraries and archives for Trajan, but his highest post was ab espistulis Â– Imperial secretary Â– to Hadrian. For 10 points name this Roman historian who wrote biographies of Julius Caesar to Domitian in The Twelve Caesars.

The city of Hecatompolis was founded during the journey to obtain these, and their captor conceived Scythes while dragging them through Hylaea. Alebion and Dercyon were killed during the retrieval of these objects. During the expedition to obtain these, one figure shot an arrow at the sun, leading to Helios granting him a golden cup. Cacus stole a subset of them by having them walk backwards. Their guardian was killed at the Anthemus river by a poisoned arrow. After Menoites reported them missing, their guardian spoke to his mother Callirhoe, who begged him not to pursue them. The herdsman Eurytion and the two-headed dog Orthrus were killed during their extraction from Erytheia, and after they were brought to Eurystheus they were sacrificed to Hera and the For 10 points, name these animals guarded by a three-bodied giant, the subject of Heracles Tenth Labor.
tossups.answer: Geryon's cattle [equivalents ok, must mention Geryon and something cow like, prompt on "cattle"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Geryon's cattle [equivalents ok, must mention Geryon and something cow like, prompt on "cattle"]

tossups.question: In a letter to Joshua Reynolds, John Boydell called this painting "The greatest effort of art since the Sistine Chapel and the Stanze of Raphael." In this painting's left background, a figure in red can be seen waving his hand as he and two others ascend up a flight of stairs. That takes place at the far end of a stone archway inside of which another man leans his hands and head against the walls in sadness. The rigid, upright pose of the central figure strongly contrasts with the swooning postures of his companions as he points his left index finger skyward while reaching for a goblet with his right hand. For 10 points, identify this painting of a philosopher as he prepares to drink hemlock, by Jacques-Louis David.

An unusual condition in which these cells self-destruct is treated by the obscenely expensive antibody eculizumab, is diagnosed by Ham's test, and is called PNH. Streptococcal species are classified by their ability to break down these cells in culture. These cells fail to differentiate in GATA-1 knockouts, and mutations in band 4.1 causes these cells to appear elliptical. These cells are broken down excessively in patients with glucose-6-phosphate deficiency. These cells hold their shape via spectrin and ankyrin proteins, and about one-third of them are sequestered in the spleen at any given time. They have a lifetime of about 120 days and a disease in which they are misshapen is caused by a glutamic acid to valine mutation in the beta-chain of hemoglobin. For 10 points, name these biconcave cells which carry oxygen and give blood its color.

The formulators of this theory performed an experiment in which they asked people what percentage of members of the UN were African nations in order to formulate the "anchoring and adjustment heuristic". A cumulative version of it is able to take framing effects into account. One of its creators, along with Knetsch and Thaler, found a violation of Coase's theorem in which a person values an object they own more than an identical object they do not own. It posits a concave value curve for gains and a convex one for losses. This model suggests that loss aversion is a disproportionate determinant of behavior. The canonical example of this theory explains why people will travel far for a large percentage discount rather than a small one. For 10 points, name this theory in behavioral economics formulated by Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman

One leader of this organization published the autobiography The Path I Trod and served two terms as mayor of Scranton, Pennsylvania. This group organized black sugar cane workers in Louisiana who were later killed in order to suppress a strike during the Thibodeaux massacre. White miners in this group slaughtered another group of immigrants in the Rock Spring Massacre, a result of this group's support for the Chinese Exclusion act. This group's secret ritual manual was the Adelphon Kruptos. It failed in its long-running conflict with Jay Gould during the Great Southwest Railroad Strike. Uriah Smith Stephens founded this group, though he was later succeeded by Terrence Powderly. FTP, name this labor organization influenced by Freemasonry that declined after the Haymarket Square Riot.

The delicate singer Clara Hibbert appears alongside the jilted Bunty Mainwaring in a play by this author, which centers on Florence Lancaster's affair with the younger Tom Veryan and her eventual confrontation with her cocaine-addled son Nicky. Another of his plays includes the line, "I'd rather marry a boa constrictor." Besides The Vortex and a play about Elyot and Amanda ditching their honeymoons and getting back together with each other, he wrote of woman on a bicycle who interrupts a dinner with the Bradmans, the medium Madame Arcati. Ruth's jealousy is manifested by the return of Charles Condomine's first wife, Elvira, as a ghost in a play by this writer, named after a line from Shelley's "To a Skylark." For ten points, name this gay author of Private Lives and Blithe Spirit.

This city saw 13 car bombings blamed on D-Company led by Dawood Ibrahim in 1993 that were in response to deadly riots over the demolition of the Babri Masjid. Another incident in this city saw pressure cookers put on trains leaving Churchgate on this city's Suburban Railway in an attack often blamed on SIMI and a native Mujahedeen group. The FBI charged David Headley with scouting target locations in this city such as the Oberoi Trident to help an attack known as 26/11. Operation Black Wind saw National Security Guards defeat Laskhar-E-Taiba terrorists that had been supported by the ISI in Pakistan. For 10 points, name this city that saw 2006 train bombings and a 2008 resort attack, the largest in India.
tossups.answer: Terrorist attacks in Mumbai or Bombay
acceptable: Terrorist attacks in Mumbai or Bombay
Terrorist attacks in Mumbai or Bombay

tossups.question: This philosopher critiqued a contemporary's book chapter titled "Philosophy as Categorical Thinking," in the paper "Mr. Collingwood and the Ontological Argument." Another of his works consists of chapters like "Achilles and the Tortoise," and "It Was To Be," and is dedicated to explicating the points of conflict between philosophical theories. A work by this philosopher argues that "mental does not denote a status" in a section which claims that mental events cannot be witnessed and which is titled "Sensation and Observation." That book contains a chapter in which this philosopher analyzes the "intellectualist legend," and the method of judging the intelligence of a performance; that chapter is titled "Knowing How and Knowing That." For 10 points, identify this philosopher who collected some of his lectures in Dilemmas and argued against the "ghost in the machine" in The Concept of Mind.

A method for distance determination using these objects, which are described by the Plummer Model, involves comparing the turnover magnitude of a sample  to that of a sample from nearby galaxies. In addition to their namesake luminosity function, these objects, which include 47 Tucanae, are observed in amounts proportional to their galaxy's luminosities. They are drawn in to the center of their galaxies by dynamical friction and their age can be determined by their turnoff point on an HR diagram. Blue Stragglers are inordinately bright and young stars that appear in these collections of old population II stars that orbit in the halo of every galaxy in the local group. FTP, name these spherical collections of old stars that are distinguished from the open variety of the same type of object by their old age.

One character in this book is terrified by winged ants during a storm, and two characters' legs turn white in this novel when they wade in a buffalo pond. The main character makes a lifeless painting of Punch and writes a series of unfinished stories all titled "Escape" in this novel, which begins with a father giving his daughter the bleak advice, "Fate. There is nothing we can do about it." This novel's protagonist moves between The Chase, Green Vale, and Hanuman House after causing his father's drowning by playing in a stream when he was supposed to be watching a calf. This novel's protagonist, who is based on the author's father Seepersad, desires autonomy symbolized by the title object. He marries Shama, daughter of the Tulsi family, which turns out to be a painful decision for Mohun in, for 10 points, what book by V.S. Naipaul?

One of this artist's proposals, a collaboration with Arata Isozaki, is a mobile concert hall that would tour Japan, called the Ark Nova. The Israel Museum contains one of his works shaped like a gigantic hourglass, entitled Turning the World Upside Down. Another of his works is a series of three parallel steel rings that are connected by a red fleshy PVC membrane. This artist of Marsyas was recently commissioned to create the structure commemorating the 2012 London Games, which is a large observation tower surrounded by a twisting red frame. The Wellington Circus theater currently contains his 10-ton concave sculpture entitled Sky Mirror. Another one of his works, which contains a navel on its underside and is found in Chicago's Millenium Park, is a large reflective bean-shaped structure. For 10 points, identify this modern British-Indian sculptor of Sky Mirror and Cloud Gate.

Because of this event, Kirk Lippold was repeatedly denied confirmation for a promotion by the US Senate despite an investigation releasing him from responsibility. By May 2008, all defendants convicted in this event had either escaped or been released from prison, and after this event Anthony Rix on the HMS Marlborough lent assistance. One response to this action was the freezing of Sudanese assets by a federal judge. The 9/11 Commission Report cites a source claiming that the lack of American response to this event, which took place in the Gulf of Aden, led the attackers to plan a bigger, more noticeable attack. FTP, name this suicide attack on an American Destroyer in Yemen in October 2000 by Al-Qaeda terrorists.

bonuses.leadin: In GUIs, these are generated when the user inputs commands, and using the Java suspend or stop command on these entities makes programs prone to deadlock. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these subsets of processes which processors multiplex using context switching. These are the smallest units of execution that can be run by a program.
The Dining Philosophers Problem, which can be used to simulate deadlock between threads, was solved using semaphores by this Dutch computer scientist
In addition to stopping deadlock, scheduling algorithms also try to stop this condition, in which a process cannot complete because the scheduler is denying it CPU time or memory that it requires.

bonuses.leadin: This man resigned from his highest office after his affair with Maria Reynolds was revealed, and along with James Madison and John Jay, he adopted the moniker Publius to write some important papers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this first Treasury Secretary of the United Sates who was shot to death in a duel with Aaron Burr.

Alexander Hamilton was a leader of this early political party, which opposed the Democratic Republicans. This party's platform included the creation of a national bank and maintaining good relations with Britain.
Hamilton's scheme to bolster the nation's credit was given this name. It involved taking in old bonds and issuing new ones that match the face value of the old bonds.

bonuses.leadin: Silicon Carbide and Gallium Arsenide are examples of these materials whose properties are enhanced by doping. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this class of material that has both holes and electrons as charge carriers. They have abnormally small band gaps which allow them to transfer from an insulative state to a charge carrying state.

These zero-dimensional semiconductor structures are useful in super-resolution imaging for their high resistance to photobleaching. Varying the size of the crystal and the band gap allows tuning of their emission wavelength.
Typical quantum dots are made with cores this Metal's Selenide or Sulfide. Usage of this heavy metal in semiconductors is being heavily reduced due to its toxicity.

bonuses.leadin: This work's fourth chapter suggests that it would be "a great misunderstanding of this doctrine, to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference," before distinguishing between personal disapproval and socially sanctioned punishment. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this philosophical work which ends by advocating " the greatest dissemination of power consistent with efficiency; but the greatest possible centralization of information, and diffusion of it from the centre."
On Liberty was written by this Englishman, whose other works include The Subjection of Women.
The first chapter of On Liberty accuses this philosopher, the author of Course on Positive Philosophy, of "aim[ing] at establishing... a despotism of society over the individual."

bonuses.leadin: Iris flies away and reports her mistreatment to Zeus in one section of this play, and one character chases away the geometer Meton in another scene. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this comedy in which Pisthetaerus takes over the city of Cloudcuckooland and blocks the offerings of the people below to the gods.
The Birds is a work by this ancient Greek playwright, who depicted the women of Greece attempting to end the Peloponnesian war using a sex strike in his Lysistrata.

This term refers to a passage in an ancient Greek play in which the chorus directly addresses the audience. In The Birds, the chorus threatens to shit on the judges if the play doesn't win the City Dionysia.

bonuses.leadin: This man caused a scandal with his suggestive paintings for the ceiling of the Great Hall at the University of Vienna. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who painted the Beethoven Frieze as well as The Kiss, which like many of his works from the 1900's uses gold leaf and a strange collage of rectangles.

Klimt painted two portraits of this wife of a businessman. Now at the Neue Galerie, that first portrait was for a time the most expensive painting ever sold and was at the center of a legal battle by the subject's niece Maria Altmann.

Klimt also created the mosaics Expectation and Tree of Life as part of this frieze for a palace in Brussels. The mosaics feature a recurring spiral motif on the tree and what appears to be the couple from The Kiss seen from a different angle with slightly different clothing.

bonuses.leadin: The servant Babo in this novella turns out to be the real leader of the San Dominick. FTPE:
answers: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.
Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life or Omoo: A Narrative of the South Seas
parts: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.

Melville, the author of Benito Cereno, also wrote the story "Billy Budd" in which the title character has a speech impediment and so resorts to punching, and incidentally killing, this other character.
Melville's first written book  involves his actual experiences in the South Pacific as a captive on Nuku Hiva. Name either that book or its sequel.
answers_formatted: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.
Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life or Omoo: A Narrative of the South Seas
acceptable: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.
Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.
Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life or Omoo: A Narrative of the South Seas
Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life or Omoo: A Narrative of the South Seas

bonuses.leadin: This composition lies on side two of the album Giant Steps along with "Syeeda's Song Flute" and "Mr. P.C." FTPE:
parts: Identify this slow ballad, featuring a piano solo despite its composer's proficiency with a different instrument, that was named for its composer's wife Juanita Grubbs.
This jazz saxophonist recorded "Naima" with his quartet including Jimmy Garrison and McCoy Tyner. He also played soprano saxophone for the album My Favorite Things.
Coltrane sings the title of this album, which begins with a gong strike. This album consists of the four parts: Acknowledgement, Resolution, Pursuance, and Psalm.

bonuses.leadin: A prince of this empire, Zannanza, was sent to Egypt because of letters from Tutankhamen's widow Ankhsenamun. For 10 points each:
answers: Labarna I [prompt on "Hattusili I" or "Labarna II" because of recent scholarship, I guess]
parts: That letter was found in this empire's capital of Hattusa and was addressed to Suppiluliuma I. This Anatolian civilization is commonly attributed with being the first with widespread iron production.

During this battle, Hittite chariots routed the Ra division but the Ptah division forced the Hittite infantry into the namesake city. King Muwatallis and Pharoah Ramses II signed the first peace treaty here.
This man is the traditional first king of the Hittites and founder of their Old Kingdom. This figure may actually just be his successor, Hattusili I, sometimes called the second of this name.
answers_formatted: Labarna I [prompt on Hattusili I or Labarna II" because of recent scholarship, I guess]
promptable: Labarna II" because of recent scholarship, I guess

bonuses.leadin: It was originally managed by Andy Warhol, who forced them to collaborate with artists such as Nico and made them part of his multimedia show 'The Exploding Plastic Inevitable.' For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 60s rock band that never achieved commercial success but is considered on of the most influential bands of the 60s. Its critically successful songs include 'Pale Blue Eyes' and 'Venus in Furs.'

This front man for the Velvet Underground had a very successful solo career after the group's split. His album "Transformer" included critically successful songs such as "Vicious" and "Walk on the Wild Side."
Name the less critically successful Lou Reed album that consists of an hour of feedback loops and noise music that eschews the conventions of good taste.

bonuses.leadin: This man beat the Russians at Raclawice with an army mostly armed with pikes and war scythes. For 10 points each:
answers: Targowica Confederation [accept Konfederacja targowicka or Targovicos konfederacija]
parts: Name this man better known for fortifying Saratoga against Burgyone and becoming the chief of the engineering corps during the American Revolutionary War.

Koxciuszko led a revolt in this country that had already lost land to Prussia, Austria, and Russia. This would lead to the third and final partition of this country after the Praga district massacre in Warsaw.

This group of Polish magnates appealed to Russia to overturn the reforms of the May 3rd Constitution. Russia sent an army to aid this group to defeat the King and Sejm, but only to partition more land for itself.

bonuses.leadin: An important function of this organ is impaired in Dubin-Johnson and Rotor syndrome, and it is a site of extramedullary hematopoiesis in the fetus along with the yolk sac. For 10 points each:
answers: Smooth ER or Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum
parts: Identify this abdominal organ, which develops fibrotic scar tissue in cirrhosis. One of its primary functions is producing bile.

Hepatocytes are responsible for detoxification; thus it makes sense that this organelle is highly developed in hepatocytes. Unlike a related organelle, it has no ribosomes on its surface, and it synthesizes lipids and steroids.

The detoxification and drug metabolism processes in the liver are performed by a family of cytochrome enzymes given this name. It gets its name from the peak wavelength of a complex created when CO is added to it.
acceptable: Smooth ER or Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum
Smooth ER or Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum

bonuses.leadin: At one point in this novel, the title character realizes with horror that the housekeeper Mrs. Jewkes might be an atheist because she is so unwomanly. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this epistolary novel about a girl enslaved by the nobleman Mr. B. The title character's virtue is rewarded because she falls in love with Mr B as he keeps forcing himself on her.
Samuel Richardson's Pamela was satirized in this man's Shamela. He also wrote a novel about the brother of Pamela who is repeatedly hit on by Lady Booby, entitled Joseph Andrews.

This literary critic heavily skewers Pamela in his The English Novel: An Introduction. This British critic also published Literary Theory: An Introduction and got into trouble for calling Kingsley Amis a drunken anti-semite.

bonuses.leadin: Henry of Huntingdon's Historia Anglorum contains the first use of this term, and this collection of kingdoms included Kent and East Anglia. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this collection of seven Anglo-Saxon kingdoms that ruled Britain until Egbert of Wessex managed to consolidate them in the late 800s.

Wessex was one of the main members of the Heptarchy. This king of Wessex defeated the Danes at the Battle of Ashdown, created a network of fortresses called Burhs, and translated Boethius' Consolation of Philosophy
This other member of the Heptarchy had its capitol at Tamworth and was ruled by a line of kings including Penda and Offa.

bonuses.leadin: It inspires one speaker to cry, "Gather, gather your youth ... Old age will tarnish your beauty." For ten points each:
answers: national epic [prompt on just epic, accept synonyms for "national"]
parts: Name this item that wears a purple dress in a poem addressed to a "Mignonne."
"Mignonne, allons voir si la Rose" was written by this "Prince of Poets" and leader of La PlÃ©iade who wrote in the French Renaissance.
Ronsard's La Franciade was intended to fulfill this role for France. These poems include Scotland's Ossian and Poland's Pan Tadeusz.
answers_formatted: national epic [prompt on just epic, accept synonyms for "national]

bonuses.leadin: This deity's grandson Ninigi was sent down to rule Japan after being given the Imperial regalia by this deity. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Shinto solar deity, the sister of Susanoo and Tsuki-yomi who hid in a cave after Susanoo went rampaging through heaven.
Amaterasu was the daughter of this deity, who was unable to retrieve his wife from the underworld. Amaterasu was born from his left eye.
Izanagi and Izanami created the island of Onogoro-shima by churning the seas with one of these objects named Ame-no-nu-hoko.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following composers of electronic music, for 10 points each:
parts: This man called for such odd instruments as turntables and radio receivers in his Imaginary Landscapes. He's probably better known for a piece consisting entirely of silence, 4'33".
This man wrote his Poeme electronique for a pavilion at the 1958 World's Fair designed by Le Corbusier. He also composed Density 21.5 to mark the invention of the platinum flute.

This American serial composer combined the synthesizer with both live and recorded soprano in his Philomel. Also noted for his contributions to theory, he examined the state of the avant-garde composer in an article for High Fidelity called "Who Cares if You Listen?"

bonuses.leadin: Milton Babbitt
parts: Identify this psychotherapist and author of On Becoming a Person, who developed a humanistic form of treatment in which a patients positive potential is realized, called client-centered therapy.

Rogers viewed this as the product of the fact that everyone exists at the center of a world of changing experience. Allport defined it using dispositions, and it is the subject of the MMPI and Meyers-Briggs indicators.

This other American humanist psychoanalyst attempted to apply existentialism to psychoanalysis. He was a friend of Paul Tillich drew a distinction between "free sex" and "free love" in his Love and Will.

bonuses.leadin: One of these substances named for Lindlar is used to transform alkynes into cis-alkenes and is notably poisoned by lead acetate. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these chemical reagents which speed up reactions by lowering the activation energy.
A catalyst that has a different phase than the molecules it acts upon is given this name. This type of catalyst is often mixed with a support in order to increase its surface area.
This process uses an Iridium complex as a catalyst in order to synthesize acetic acid. This process replaces the less efficient Monsanto process.

bonuses.leadin: The Synod of Barmen of May 1934 was held to create a theological declaration for this religion which was opposed by a group that wanted to remove all of the Old Testament from Christianity.FTPE, name:
parts: This Nazi era religion that opposed the "German Christian" Faction 's attempts to remove Jewish influence from Christianity. The author of the "First they came" poem, Martin Niemoller was a leader of this group.
This other leader of the Confessing Church gave a radio speech denouncing Hitler and warning against a cult of the Fuhrer. He was later executed at Flossenburg for his part in the July 20 conspiracy.

This Pope who reigned during WWII signed the Reichskonkordat with the Nazi Government to give the Catholic Church rights in Germany. He issued Mit Brennender Sorge in response to the many violations of the treaty.
